turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Number 39, Alfonse Bartkus versus the People of the State of Illinois.
Mr. Fisher.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court.
This is a criminal case.
I represent a prisoner in the Illinois Penitentiary.
He is serving a sentence, a life sentence for bank robbery.
This Court granted his petition for certiorari from the Illinois Supreme Court's affirmance of his conviction and appointed counsel for petitioner.
Our principal -- our principal contention is that the State of Illinois has not accorded petitioner due process of law under the Fourteenth Amendment.
We submit that the facts of this case show a disregard of due process in several quite different respects.
The variety of bad procedures that were applied to this man is striking.
The procedural facts surrounding his trial are malodorous, but the Court need not reach the doctrine of the facts as a whole being so shocking as to deny the due process.
We contend that they are with the specific denials of due process or in themselves quite sufficient grounds for reversal.
The two most critical issues are, first, that Illinois tried him over again after he had been acquitted by a federal court.
And second, and it is entirely separate and independent ground of reversal, that Illinois convicted him on the basis of unconstitutional activities of federal officers.
Here are the facts and they are not disputed.
In 1953, a savings and loan association in Cooke County was robbed by two arms men.
They took some $4000 and fled in a car.

The driver was waiting in the car, petitioner, then 26 years old, heard that he was wanted and he went to United States Marshal's Office where he was arrested and charged with being the driver of that car.
And his defense was simply that they had the wrong man.
At the trial of petitioner, the identity of the driver of the car was the only issue.
He took the stand, he and other witnesses testified that he was far away from the robbery at the time it occurred and the testimony against him was by alleged accomplices.
This trial was in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Illinois and it was for violation of the Federal Bank Robbery Act.
The basis of federal jurisdiction was the savings and loan association, which was robbed, was federally insured, insured for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.
Incidentally, 94% of all savings and loan associations in this country are federally insured.
And the existence of the insurance was stipulated in this case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do you have the percentages on banks also, Mr. Fisher?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: That are insured by the FDIC?
I think 87% -- 87% of banks, as I recall, are -- are insured.
That's both state and national banks.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: It's all banks, national and state, 14,777 only are not insured by the FDIC.
Petitioner was found not guilty by the federal jury and was acquitted.
Now, we come to the facts bearing on other point, the activities of the federal officers.
The United States District Judge was dissatisfied with the verdict and he proceeded to criticize the jury in most unusual fashion.Some of the details are in our brief.
The judge's conduct and the widespread publicity that was given to it were of the nature to encourage the retrial of petitioner in the state court.
And the States Attorney of Cooke County said on the record that the federal authorities came to him after petitioner's federal acquittal.
Petitioner was turned over to state custody and indicted the second time for the same robbery.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Was your man the only defendant in the criminal -- in the federal case?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: In -- in the federal case, he had two accomplishes but they were not -- they were not tried with him.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: They were not tried.
He was the sole defendant.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: No.
He was the sole defendant.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did they plead guilty of it?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Did they plead guilty?
They weren't tried.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Were they indicted?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: They -- I don't think they were indicted at this time.
I'm not sure of that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Does the record show?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: I don't think the record shows.
They were -- I happen to know that they -- I don't think Mr. Wines objected.
They were subsequently -- they were subsequently placed under -- under the federal -- under parole under the Federal Parole Act.
Now, in spite of -- of petitioner's acquittal by the federal court, the Federal Government kept on working for his conviction.

The FBI agents in -- disregard, as we contend, of the double jeopardy provision of the Fifth Amendment, interviewed one of petitioner's alibi witnesses and turned over the information to the state authorities.
A special agent and the United States Attorney also interviewed an entirely new witness, one had not testified in the previous case.
And they asked the new witness to come in to the state court and testify.
The federal agents did the interviewing.
The Illinois prosecutor did not talk with this new witness until the day he testified at the state trial.
This activity of the federal officers, as I say, is an entirely independent ground of reversal separate from the former acquittal point.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Fisher, are all these facts that you cited thus far, I suppose the full --

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- record -- is -- is the record in the federal trial before us?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: That was not -- that was not put in issue in this case, but the case was tried on the basis that the issues were the same except for the alibi.
The Supreme Court of Illinois so treated the matter.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I didn't mean -- I didn't mean the substantive prosecutions but in the recitals that you gave --

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: In the recitals that I've given --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- by conduct --

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: -- that they are all --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- of the District Judge and the activities of federal official, are they acquitted?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: They are all in -- they are all in there.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In this little --

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: No, they're either in the brief or that book, either our brief or in that record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But the -- the stenographic record is with the Clerk, is it?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: The stenographic record is with the Clerk.
Except the fact that I mentioned about what happened to the -- to the accomplices, alleged accomplices is subsequent to that -- to that, I did -- I have given --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Can you tell me whether -- can we look at the proceeding?
Should it be deemed relevant in the District Court, the United States District Court?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: You see, he was acquitted so that no significant of evidence was made and there is -- there is a stenographic record of it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what I mean.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: That's not in evidence in any way.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But for instance, the remarks you -- you --

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: It's not certified or in evidence.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- you found some relevance to the remarks of the judge and etcetera.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Those -- those remarks are from newspaper clippings in the Chicago press that I have appended to my brief --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They are in -- they are before us.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: -- Your Honors.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: And I felt justified in doing that because this became such a famous matter that this judge attempted to defend himself in another case and his action in this case that they were so severely criticized in Chicago that he attempted to defend himself and it came into the record another case, went up to the -- the Court of Appeals for our circuit.
And there, it was discussed by both the majority and the dissenting judge as a matter of common knowledge.
And it upper to me --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's because --

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: -- that under those circumstances that this Court could take judicial notice of those facts.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's because I assumed it may be relevant that I am asking whether the -- whether the materials are here before us.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: If our position is that the federal officers utilized the state court as their instrument in doing what the Federal Government is forbidding to do with the double jeopardy provision of the Fifth Amendment.
And that, we submit, is not due process of law under the Fourteenth Amendment.
The issue, as I've said in the second trial, was the same as that in the first trial.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I'm sorry to interrupt again, but you -- your last statement, it becomes very important if your contention is that the activities of federal officials from the judge down constituted a violation of the double jeopardy of the Fifth Amendment as an injunction upon federal activities, then it becomes very important that all the materials bearing on that be properly before this Court.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Those materials were -- were in the record as to the activities of these officers.
The test -- the fact that the interviewing of the witnesses and turning over to the evidence to the state authorities is in the record, Mr. Justice.
The only thing that I said was not in the record and from the newspaper clippings was the -- were the statements of the Federal District Judge.
The issue in the second trial, as I have said, was the same as in the first and that issue was the identity of the person driving the car used in the escape.
This is all perfectly clear from the opinion of the Illinois Supreme Court, and it is not disputed.
And petitioner was found guilty in the second case.
Now, the reason why he received life imprisonment was because it was mandatory under the Illinois second offender statute then enforced.
That statute provided that a prior conviction in a different case be mentioned in the indictment and brought to the attention of the jury.
And there are statutes like that in a number -- in the number of States.

And that feature of the statute, however, I am glad to say has been repealed this year, so that Illinois is no longer in what I regard as the disgraceful position for juries are told of former offenses, where they must be told a former offenses if the habitual criminal feature is to be used.
If the second offender feature is to be used, you have to put it in the indictment under this old statute.
But, of course, the repeal is not retroactive, it does not apply to my client.

Now, in addition to these two points I have mentioned, and we do, in our brief, raised as an independent ground of reversal, but we regard as an extremely unfair application of that provision to this case.
And I'm sure we will not have time today to argue with it orally.
Today, I want to argue with three grounds of reversal orally, and they are separate and independent grounds of each other.
One is that petitioner was tried over again after being acquitted for identically the same affair.
The second is the unconstitutional participation of the federal officers.
And the third is encroachment by the State of Illinois on the judicial power of the United States.
Now, on our first point, it's undisputed that the second trial different from the first in only two respects, the fact that the federal insurance did not have to be proved in the state case.
And the second trial occurred in the state court rather in the federal court.
Those are the only differences.
Now, such differences have been thought in various cases to permit double prosecutions.
But we disagree and we contend that from the standpoint of due process, those two differences are not of a nature to justify a second trial for what is in fact the same offense.
Due Process is, of course, a matter of substance.
And this question is an open question for this Court, as I propose to show.

Putting it in other words, I propose to show that it was the same offense in both trials, the same offense in both trials, and that the matter of the difference in jurisdictions ought not to make any difference.
Now, of course, our premise is that under the Fourteenth Amendment, the State of Illinois, by itself, may not keep on prosecuting a man after he has been acquitted.
Our position here is based on the defense in this -- this big part of our case.
Our position is based on the defense of former acquittal not on double jeopardy as a whole.
We contend that the inviability of a former acquittal is part of due process of law.
And Palko against Connecticut and other cases of this Court have expressly left that question open.
In our brief --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: You mean that -- you mean that if he had been convicted of federal trial that you think -- you say he could have been retried again --

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: I don't think --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- in Illinois?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: -- I don't think he ought to be.
I'm candid to say, Mr. Justice, that that is not our case.
Our case is acquittal and acquittal is thoroughly distinguishable from former conviction that has -- that has been distinguished as we show in our briefs since the time of the yearbooks.
It's absolutely fundamental part of order of liberty.

It goes back way behind -- before the right of counsel and it is -- if you think that defense of former conviction which is always -- as a separate plea of common law, if you feel that that is a separate -- is a separate matter and is important and is part of due process, why, former acquittal is even more sacred.
Now, today, I'm going to assume that it is clear beyond doubt that Illinois couldn't try a man who've been acquitted over again for identically the same thing.
I mean take the example which is not our case with a crime for something that is admittedly the same offense under, identically, the same statute.
I don't believe that the Illinois was seriously content that it will keep on trying a man over again under the same statute for the -- for the same offense constitutionally.
I'd say -- I believe we have lots of material but I will assume it now.
Now, leaving aside for the moment the matter of the two jurisdictions, the state and the federal, we contend that the federal and state offenses are the same offense for purposes of double jeopardy.

In other words, before we get to the matter of the two jurisdictions, I must first persuade you that neither the Federal Government acting alone nor the State acting alone could try a man twice for the same act of robbery under two federal statutes that are similar as these two statutes here or under two state statutes, it different no more than the two statutes in this case.
That's what I must persuade you first.
Later, we reach our position that what they cannot do separately, they cannot do in combination.
Defendant was tried the second time for identically the same convict as in the first trial.
He wasn't accused of robbing different banks or different people as in the whole case that has been set to follow this case in argument.
Our case now is not a case involving fragmentation of crime for purposes of increasing the punishment.
That's like the Ladner case which comes after the Hoag case that has been set in this group of three.
Ladner is a punishment case.
It's not a double jeopardy case at all.
There was only one trial.
You can't have double jeopardy unless there are two trials.
And what isn't appropriate unit of crime, unit of the crime or unit of prosecution is -- is a different thing in punishment cases and it isn't a double jeopardy case.
The appropriate -- the appropriate unit might permit a man's punishment to be increased if it cuts more mail bags, for example, or if he steals more money.
But that doesn't mean that a man can constitutionally be retried for each unit or for each piece of paper money.
Punishment can be graded for -- for the size and number of the offense.
It's -- it's clear from reading all these cases that there is no such thing as a unit of the crime for all purposes.
Now, this Court has ruled that there are two offenses for purposes of double jeopardy and each statute requires proof of an additional fact which the other statute does not.
But surely, this is basic.
That's separate fact must have some significance, some significance in the way of a separate statutory purpose or policy.
And I think I can demonstrate that.

The Federal Bank Robbery Act makes it a crime to rob a national bank, a member of the Federal Reserve System, a member of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and maybe those are separate offenses now.
But let's suppose the Congress removes all question and specifically makes them separate offenses.

In similar fashion, Illinois could, of course, make separate offenses of robbing a state bank, a member of the Federal Reserve System, a member of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the States, of course, are free to -- to protect federal institutions and separate offensive robbery in the bank building, robbery after nightfall, robbery with a gun, robbery with a mask, a dozen more offenses, each with its unique fact to be proved as required by that statute.
And those would be perfectly good separate offenses for purposes of counts and for purposes of punishment, for purposes of the prosecutor's option as to which he shall try.
But it is a very different thing to say that they create separate offenses so as to allow a man to be acquitted one or more times and then tried over and over again for the same transaction.
I'm sure this Court would never stand for it.

Unless this separate fact in each of these statutes would reflect some separate purpose or policy to permit retrials would reduce the Constitution -- would -- would deprive the Constitution of substance.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: From what do you derive the differences, your qualification interest me, unless it represent some different purpose of policy from what do you derived the difference in purpose of policy?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: It's the function of this Court, it seems to me, to decide whether a difference -- is the difference of words merely, a verbal difference, a different sub trivialities or a difference of constitutional substance.
And to say that you could -- that you -- a man can be tried twice federally, and I'm not talking about the two jurisdictions now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: -- tried twice federally or twice by a State for robbing the same institution because one time it's a member of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and other time that it's a member of the Federal Reserve System is something I am certain this Court would never stand for as a matter of constitutional law.
That's not what the Constitution is.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I suppose -- I suppose knocking down a postman in the -- in the post office building in Chicago which is both an obstruction of the mail, that he is carrying a mail back and also the (Inaudible) assimilation statute in which they -- those are two clearly different purposes, is that it?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: No, no.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You wouldn't.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Not unless the mails are being interfered with.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I'm saying he's -- he's trying to deliver something and he (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: That might -- that might easily be a separate purpose.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I understand that.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: It's up to this -- it's up to this Court --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He's trying to get a distinction.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: This Court must decide each time whether there is -- whether there's substance in the difference or not.
It must decide whether it's a matter of form or a matter of substance.
You can't take the case -- take the case of a -- take the case of a man being convicted of assault in the State and then being tried federally for deprivation of the civil right to vote.
It would appear there, it's a very strong ground to argue.
And it would seem to me, there was a separate policy there, quite a separate policy.
But this -- the bank robbery statute is not that kind of a -- of a statute.

The bank -- the -- the legislative history of the Bank Robbery Act makes it clear that the only purpose of the Bank Robbery Act was to assist state enforcement, to provide the resources of federal enforcement, to help stop roving gang or interstate gangs of bank robbers.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It might make a difference if the punishments are drastically different and the amount of proof, bank robbery involving element of violence that is -- it interferes with some other aspect of banking might merely be something with a small punishment that interferes with something else.
I'm not saying it is.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Yes, of course, it would be a different policy.
The standard case in the textbooks is out of a man who's tried for selling liquor to a minor on Sunday.
There are two entirely different statutory purposes there.
And you might have given the case in my case for example.
My man was accused of being in the getaway car.
Now, I supposed he'd been tried for illegal parking by a hydrant, that would be entirely separate purpose.
And this was brought out in the case that is cited in this Court, the case of this Court that is often cited in this connection, that's the Javier case from the Philippine Islands.
And that case is cited over and over again with the State.

It is repeated that its -- its two-statute, its two offenses if there are -- if there are two separate statutory requirements.But in -- in the Javier case, itself, in the opinion of that Court, The Court referred to the separate gist of the two statutes there involved.

There were other minor offenses but remind the Court in Javier, the man was tried one time for creating a brawl under Philippine law and other time for insulting an official and the Court found -- the Court went into the inquiry and inquire as to the -- as to the gist of the offenses.
They -- they referred to it right there and they said, "These offenses have a different gist," sometimes the word "gravamen" is used.
Social purpose or policy is sometimes used.
But there is no difference in the -- in these bank robbery statutes.
The Federal Act, as I say, was simply concerned with enforcement.

And the jurisdictional requirement, the jurisdictional requirement of federal insurance in the case of bank robbery is like the jurisdictional requirement that for Illinois to prosecute, the offense must be committed in Illinois.
That must be proved.
Mr. Wines refers to that, I believe, in one of the earlier briefs in the case.
That's not his.
But, of course, the act was committed in Illinois.
Well, here, we have -- we have to prove the jurisdictional requirement and the crime had to be proved that this institution was robbed, the institution was insured.

A decision for petitioner would not create a precedent against retrials in -- in civil rights cases or in any other case where the Court inquires into the matter to find out whether there's a substantial difference in these statutes.
In our reply brief, on page 5, we show how foreign countries will not retry a man who's been acquitted in another country.

The notion that because there are two sovereignties, you should try a man over again is -- is not only unfounded and as far as the common law jurisdictions are concern, it is unfounded as far as -- as most -- more advanced European countries are concerned.
But they won't retry a man.

But there's always an exception under the law of France and those -- some other countries, in treason or other national security cases because there, the foreign country would have a different policy.
But everybody is united, all countries, all civilized countries and certainly, the States and the nation are united in one common policy against bank robbery.
But the mere fact that federal jurisdiction alone cannot create a separate policy.

That's the -- that's -- that seemed to be sufficiently clear that couldn't be done but we can go back to the fact that the States are free to enforce federal -- protect federal rights in the early part of the history of our country that that was the standard way for the first -- for the first half century I believe.
The states courts -- and states were largely relied upon to protect federal rights as in counterfeiting.
And a State could pass a statute making it a crime to rob a bank.It's a member of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, for example.

Let's say that -- that -- the State having to create in such a crime and the Federal Government having also create in such a crime, makes it necessarily a separate policy because the -- because the jurisdictions are different, because the Federal Government always have a separate policy.
It's obviously without substance.
That's obviously a form of -- of verbalistic conceptualism.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Wasn't there in any case, Mr. Fisher, involving these questions as between federal prosecution for counterfeiting and state prosecution for the same act on the score of fraud?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Yes, and they've held there were different policies.Some of the State, there were different policies because the state policy was directed simply against fraud and the federal policy was to protect the currency and that may very well be.
I do not quarrel with that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You -- you don't quarrel with that?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: I don't quarrel with any -- I don't quarrel with any decision for -- that -- that is founded in reason where there is a different policy.
But I do quarrel with saying because there are two statutes or two jurisdictions ipso facto they are different.
That would deprive our Constitution of substance and reduce the double jeopardy provision to a form of words.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, it's not -- it wouldn't -- it wouldn't depending on what the limitation against double jeopardy for they -- it binds two different countries.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Yes, yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So, you have to -- you have to clear that area.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The mere identity of offenses doesn't take care of the facts --

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: That's -- that's --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- that you've got two different lawmaking bodies.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: That's so far as I've gone so far.
Here's perhaps a good place to mention that a collusive trial never bars a second trial.
That is under established common law principles.
And the rationale, of course, is that if it was collusive, why the man was never in jeopardy.
Now, I've come to the critical issue of prosecution by different jurisdictions where the Court finds the offenses would otherwise be the same.

In the first place, the defense of former acquittal is for the protection of the accused and is neither the protection is identically the same whether the successive prosecutions or by the same or separate sovereignties.
The injustice to him is the same.
From his standpoint, it is the same.
And it is my contention that both on reason and on authority, the two -- the two situations should be treated in the same way.
Now, the English common law authorities are clearly and flatly on our side.
As early as 1678, it was settled in the leading case of Rex against Hutchinson, on our brief at page 40, that a man acquitted in Portugal could not be tried again in England.
And there are other -- other cases just as strong.
Our brief cites them and also American Colonial materials.
Now, there's quite a number of state and lower federal court cases against us but they do not seem at all persuasive and neither or certain dicta of this Court.
And as for the dicta of this Court, their expressions of this Court also on our side and in our brief, we analyzed those and fully discussed them.
We discussed the liquor prohibition case of United States against Lanza decided in 1922 which is a weak and distinguishable case.

It is exclusively argued as a construction of the Volstead Act and the Court, in dealing with the constitutional question, considered only the effect of the Eighteenth Amendment Clause which gives the States concurrent jurisdiction, concurrent power to enforce.
And this concurrent power to enforce didn't occur to that phrase.
It occurs nowhere else in the Constitution, and it's now out of the Constitution.
Furthermore, in Lanza, there had been a prior conviction.
It wasn't an acquittal and the case has been severely criticized by Professor Grant in his article that accompanies our brief by Professor Wexler.
The American Law Institute is against it.
Now, in this Lanza case furthermore, the vital common law authorities were not mentioned in the briefs.
I've read them.
And the case has other weaknesses that I'll go into in the brief.
For one thing, the first trial doesn't seem to have been a jury trial which has an application that I'll come to in a moment.
It's clear that the issue of whether the one jurisdiction can retry a man acquitted by the other is still an open question for this Court.
Now, once Lanza is eliminated, the only remaining argument for double trials is that the federal-state relationship requires it.

The argument implies that expediency and the practicalities of American federalism require us to do something that is otherwise constitutionally treated as an injustice and something which England and France, for example, will not do as between foreign countries.

Now, I propose to show that not only does American federalism not require such a shameful result but that in practice and policy, federal-state relations would be improved if it would -- do not -- if you don't have it, it actually be harmed by the extension of any such rule.

The heart of the argument, of course, is that unless the State is allowed to relitigate federal criminal judgments, the Federal Government would equally be prevented from relitigating state judgments and that would be a limitation on the federal judicial power.
Now, we think -- I think the rule ought to work both ways, state and federal and federal and state.
But we do not agree that the Federal Government can or should try a man over again who's been acquitted by the State.

For one thing, the Seventh Amendment prevents it, at least if the man was tried by a jury, and that's why I alluded to the fact that I can't find any evidence that in Lanza, the man was tried by the State of Washington jury.
But those are jury in the case at bar.
The petitioner was acquitted by a jury.
In this connection, I refer to the second clause of the Seventh Amendment which is a relatively unfamiliar part of it.
Unfamiliar at least, as I judge, because they're -- how do you know a case is on it?
Here's what it says, I'll read it.
"No fact tried by a jury should be otherwise reexamined in any court of the United States than according to the rules of the common law."
So the man can't be retried anyway by the Federal Government if he had a jury trial.

So, we don't need to protect -- we don't need to perpetuate this injustice or extend it in order to allow the Federal Government to retry a man because the Seventh Amendment prevents him from being retried anyway.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But don't you think the beginning of Article 7 governs the whole of it in suits at common law?
Is a criminal trial a suit at common law in that sense?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: The Seventh Amendment is generally entitled in the manuals, civil trials.
That was --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The manual entitles it but just as his own words.
I wouldn't curb it or confine it by the --

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: No, almost all --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- by the manual labor.
But in suits at common law (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Well, this Court has found, Your Honor, that the second clause is a substantial and independent clause.
But let's suppose that it only applies to civil trials, and I'll now accept that for the purposes of further discussion.
I don't agree with it but in view of what this Court has said, it would be an independent --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't know.
You don't agree and I don't know.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Well, I don't agree with it but I'll accept it and say it only applies to civil trials, but look where this brings us.
It is impossible to believe that when the Bill of Rights was adopted, the jury verdicts in criminal cases who intended to be given less protection than in civil cases.
And certainly at that time, the general public sentiment was at least as much concerned with criminal matters as with civil.

Therefore, if the second clause of the Seventh Amendment fails to include criminal trials, it could hardly be because our ancestors intended that state criminal jury verdicts should be subject to reexamination in federal courts.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't think your historic was turning -- starting point is correct.
However, it's terrible it may seem that all sorts of advantages or rather handicaps that a defendant had in a criminal case that a defendant in a civil suit did not have.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Well, there was -- they're in the original --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He couldn't be a witness.
He couldn't take the stand defended.
He couldn't have a lawyer, federal attendant.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: In the original constitution also I agree, Your Honor, that there was a lot of effort to protect property rights and vested rights.

But, when they came around to adopting the Bill of Rights, the shoe is on the other foot and at that time, it would not have been at all popular to suggest it that -- that criminal verdicts could be reexamined.

But even -- but take on reason, Holmes said for unanimous court in the Oppenheimer case, it cannot be that the safeguards of the person are less than the safeguards that protect from a liability in debt and Stoll against Gottlieb in 305 United States with the same effect.

If the second clause of the Seventh Amendment is, by any possibility, applicable only to civil trials, it must have been because everybody assumed that the reexamination of state criminal verdicts was forbidden elsewhere in the Constitution and there was a plain clause in there to which that construction could readily be given, namely, the double jeopardy provision of the Fifth Amendment.
It seems to me in its inescapable inference from the second clause of the Seventh Amendment that a federal retrial after a state acquittal is unconstitutional.
We have some historical materials that we cite in our brief that support this to some extent.

So even if this Court is not convinced by this argument based on the Seventh Amendment, I submit that it is unsound federalism to call another jury of Illinois citizens to try a man over again who has been acquitted by one jury of Illinois citizens.

That would be that in order to prevent the exceptional case of an individual going free after one inadequate trial as the judge thought it was inadequate in this case, it would make a rule that everybody is subject to two real trials and that is not the way to promote respect for our principles in our courts.
And there are other and better ways in protecting federal jurisdiction.
Congress can always take over the field to a greater or less extent.
There is always federal preemption.
The only purpose of a federal retrial is to assert federal supremacy.
And the normal way to do this, the normal constitutional way to do it is through the preemption power and the resources of federal preemption or ample and manifold.
It wouldn't be necessary for Congress to take over the whole of any field.
That's not an attractive remedy.
Concurrent jurisdiction is a great part of our constitutional system.
But there could be easily be a partial preemption.

For example, the Congress might provide that a State couldn't prosecute for federal bank robbery until, say, 30 days after notifying the United States Attorney, so that he would have an opportunity to proceed first.
That would produce only one trial and would preserve federal supremacy.
There's no reason for worrying about loosing anything by depriving the Federal Government of the right to try a man, an -- an acquitted man over again.
In our brief, we cite materials to show that double prosecutions are not favored by either the States or the nation.

The American Law Institute is against them and most people don't think they can take place when the -- when the statute against interstate transportation of automobiles to direct was passed and that was a few years before Lanza.
The original draft contained a section prohibiting double prosecutions.

But Mr. Dyer (ph) explained to Congress that where a man has been tried upon the merits in a criminal matter and the case has been disposed of, why, is not a bar anyway to further prosecution and they left it out.
While the State and the nation are separate sovereignties, they're not separate like foreign countries.

Suppose a man shot across a state line, now, in other cases to the effect that an acquittal or conviction in one State is not a bar to a prosecution in the other but that is not the view of Justice Brewer of this Court, who, for a unanimous court in 1909 said, "Where an act is malum in se prohibited and punishable by the laws of both States, the one first acquiring jurisdiction of the person may prosecute the offense, and its judgement is a finality in both States, so that one convicted," I'm still quoting, "so that one convicted or acquitted in the courts of the one State cannot be prosecuted for the same offense in the courts of the other.
Now, that was dictum.
But this Court has never held to the contrary.
And we submit that it expresses the proper rule for all situations of concurrent jurisdiction between different States or between the States and the nation.
And that is the -- is the rule of sound federalism that Congress protect the federal jurisdiction under the Supremacy Clause in any one of the manifold number of cases.
We show in our brief --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where is that -- where is that broad dicta -- broad statement from, Mr. Fisher?

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Nielsen against Oregon, 213 U.S. 115.
That's a fish trap case involving commercial fishing in the Columbia river.
We show in our brief how the smooth workings of the federal-state relationship would be enhanced by recognition of the rule of no retrials.

The cooperation has now reached the point where due to the fingerprinting work of the FBI, fingerprinting and the FBI laboratories which of the service of every police departments throughout the State is a joint effort.

And if Your Honors remember a case in this Court last spring where the cooperation is so complete, that a Chicago policeman went in the man's car and was trailed by two narcotics, they are federal narcotics agents all by prearrangement.
My time is -- is going to a close, Your Honors, but I want to mention my third point.
I will not argue now because I haven't time anymore than I have, these federal officers point, but it's -- it's fully set forth in the brief.

Our third major ground for reversal is completely independent of the Fourteenth Amendment and it is that retrial by a State after a judgement of acquittal by a federal court is an unconstitutional encroachment on the federal judicial power.

But this point was not argued below, but it seems to us that this Court, on its own motion, may wish to consider it for its own value and also it's really relevant because it shows what a serious box we will be in if the defense of former acquittal is not sustained here.
Now, here is the point in the word.
After a federal court has tried a man and acquitted him, is it not a mockery of the federal judicial power for the State to retry him for the same offense and reverse the decision?

If Lanza is not limited by the present case, the States will be invited to engage in the general practice of trying people over again on the same accusation which they've been acquitted in the federal courts.
They've made -- many prosecutors may feel it's their unwelcome duty to do it.
The States may create state offenses exactly paralleling federal offenses.

Finality of judgement is an essential attribute of judicial power and if -- within the situation I have suggested that -- that occurred, finality of judgement would be gone and that judicial power has been occupied by legislation.
Congress has already acted to give the federal courts authority to exercise the federal judicial power to prevent this violation.
Section 1738 of the Judicial Code requires the States to give full faith and credit to federal judicial proceedings.
In Section 1651, authorizes this Court to issue its writ of mandate to protect and effectuate the federal judgment that was entered below.
In short, a reversal here was required if -- for no other reason than to protect the supremacy of the federal judicial power.
If I have a few more moments, I'd like to save them for rebuttal, Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You may, Mr. Fisher.
Mr. Wines.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: May it please the Court.

Your Honors, the principle question propounded by this case has been clearly delineated by Mr. Fisher and his fair elusive statement of the facts relieves me of a burden of restating them in any detail.
The facts are, as Mr. Fisher has said, that the petitioner was indicted in the Northern District of Illinois for the robbery of a savings and loan association that was federally insured.

He was acquitted in that Court and concededly with the assistance of federal law officers was retried in the Illinois courts for the same bank robbery where he was convicted under our Habitual Criminals Act.
The principle question raised by petitioner is whether the acquittal in the federal court barred prosecution in the state court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Does your -- does your statement, Mr. Wines, of the fidelity of Mr. Fisher's statement of the fact cover is reference to the participation of federal officials in the state prosecution?

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: Yes.
Now, federal officials did unquestionably assist in the -- in the state prosecution.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: De facto they were active -- they were active and cooperative in the state prosecution.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: Yes.

Now, Your Honors, I should first like to say, opening the argument of this question, that the overwhelming consensus of theoretical expression both on the part of the courts and commentators has been since early times that conviction or acquittal, and I repeat, or acquittal in the forums of the national sovereign does not bar a retrial for the same facts in the forums of the state sovereign or vice versa.

And in Palko against Connecticut, to which I know I address myself, this Court has held that even acquittal in the courts of a State doesn't bar retrial in the courts of that State under the Fourteenth Amendment if there's nothing in the state law to inhibit such retrial.
And may I now address Palko against Connecticut.
In Connecticut, there was the time with the Palko case enforce the statute that had been enacted in 1886.
Unlike the laws of most States, Connecticut law allowed the State to appeal a verdict of acquittal for error of law.
Palko was tried on an indictment charging him with murder in the first degree which offense, if conviction should result, was punished by -- punishable by death at that time.
Mind you, the indictment charged him with murder in the first degree.
He was found guilty of murder in the second degree.

Now, under the most elementary teachings, the conviction of a lesser offense, where the indictment charge a greater offense, operates as an acquittal of the greater offense where an indictment charges murder or conviction of manslaughter operates as an acquittal of murder where an indictment charge is robbery, but the verdict is only conviction of larceny and operates as an acquittal of the greater crime of robbery.

Notwithstanding this verdict, Connecticut appealed, State appealed to Connecticut's own Supreme Court and that Court found reversible error in failure to exclude -- to admit a confession and in other respects not material here.

The Supreme Court of Connecticut reversed at the State's instance not at the defendant's instance, the verdict remanded the case and Palko was tried in a trial presumably free from these errors that the -- that it infected the first trial.
And this time, if the Court please, he was found guilty of the murder in the first degree and he was sentenced to death.
This Court granted certiorari.
The opinion but was by Mr. Justice Cardozo and he spoke for a unanimous court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not quite.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Not quite.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: Not quite, I'm sorry.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Justice what?

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: I beg your pardon, there was one dissent.
Mr -- Mr. Justice Cardozo held in the plainest of terms that the Due Process Clause does not, of its own vigor, inhibit retrials even by the same sovereign and even after acquittal.
I -- I'm aware that the Court does not like extended reading from the text but there are two sentences of Mr. Justice Cardozo, with the Chief Justice's permission, I should like to read and adopt.

He says at page 323 of the official report, Right mind of men, as we learn from these opinions, could reasonably even mistakenly believe that a second trial was lawful and prosecution subject to the Fifth Amendment if it was all in the same case.
Even more plainly, right minded men could reasonably believe than in spousing that conclusion, they were not favoring a practice repugnant to the conscience of mankind.
And Mr. Justice Cardozo declared that retrials after acquittal do not so violate the concept of ordered liberty as to deny due process under the Fourteenth Amendment.

Now, if the Court please, a leading case, and I want to say that Illinois is fully cognizant that on this Court's grant of certiorari, question is presumably open here for reconsideration on principle notwithstanding the pronouncements of earlier decisions, but a case that explorers, the conception of dual sovereignty extensively and imported the major deliberations and conclusions of this Court is United States against Lanza in 260 U.S. 377.
In that case, the defendants were charged in the federal court with the sale, manufacture, transporting and having in their possession of the same liquor is that involve in the state prosecution.
Now, it's true, as petitioner's counsel points out that in the Lanza case, there had been no trial in the state courts.
That is true.

Nevertheless, the case was argued, considered and treated in and by this Court as involving the question of the right of both sovereigns, national and state to prosecute the same defendants for the same alleged offense.

And in the Lanza case, again, if I may read just a few words, the Court said at page 382, We have here two sovereignties deriving power from different sources capable of dealing with the same subject matter within the same territory.
Continuing Mr. Cardozo says, Each may, without interference by the other enact laws to secure prohibition where the end that no legislation can give validity to acts prohibited by the Amendment.
The Court goes on to say that every citizens of the United States is also a citizen of a State or territory.
And in Moore against Illinois, now, that case involved a violation of the slave -- slavery laws so it is not exactly an advance sheet case.

But in that case, the Supreme Court of the United States declared, as the Court held in the Lanza case, that every citizens of the United States is also a citizen of a State or territory that he may be said to allow or allegiance to do sovereigns and maybe liable to punishment for an infraction of the laws of either.

Now, even when the same sovereign prosecutes for the same state of facts, if the same state of facts constitutes two separate offenses such that although only one set of fact is involved, each offense, the offenses are not identical and in one offense, something has to be proved that does not have to be proved in the other offense, dual prosecution does not result in double jeopardy.

The expressions of this Court on the point are rather few, but in the case of Carter against McClaughry, 183 U.S. 365, cited in our brief, this case had before a habeas corpus proceeding that arose in the military law, a court-martial proceeding.
In that case, the officer had been charged separately with the making of false federal warrants or requisition for funds and with an attempt to defraud the United States.
What he had actually done was obtained the money from the United States by false warrants.
And this Court held that a conviction upon both of those specifications didn't vitiate.

It was not vitiated by the inhibitions against double jeopardy and quoting from an opinion by Mr. Justice Gray in the Supreme Court of Massachusetts, the Court says, The conviction or acquittal, the conviction or acquittal upon when indictment is no barred with subsequent conviction and sentence upon another unless the evidence required to support a conviction upon one of them would have been sufficient to warrant a conviction upon the evidence.

Now, I think, Your Honors, that I can best express the gist of Illinois' contention in these considerations and reflections.We realized that on Constitution or any other question that come before this Court, consensus, virtue unanimity or even complete unanimity of juridical thought on the part of lower courts, law professors, writers, other jurists, even this Court's own previous decisions are never conclusive.

But the question involved in this case, Your Honors, is whether the retrial by Illinois of a man who has been acquitted in the federal courts for the same alleged malefactions, so violence the concept of ordered liberty, so offense the universal sense of justice as to deny due process of law.

Now, I submit, Your Honors, with all the earnestness of my command that when a prosecution is in accordance with the overwhelming consensus of juridical opinion, both that of courts and that of commentary, it can't possible so far offend the concept of ordered liberty as to deny due process and until this Court granted certiorari in this and to companion cases, there wasn't, so far as my researches have gone or so far as Mr. Fisher's researches have gone at least in contemporary times, there was a time when the question had not been the subject of expression, very much any doubt at all that prosecutions by two sovereigns were permissible and admissible even though the same facts were relied upon.
I might say in passing that the federal statute did require a proof of one additional element that was not required by the Illinois statute.
And that additional element was that the institution that was the subject of the robbery must have been federally insured.

In that case -- in this case, however, the effect of such federal insurance was supplied by stipulation but I don't rest my argument principally upon the ground that Illinois had to prove less to convict the petitioner.

Less facts, I don't mean -- I didn't have to prove the facts but it did have to prove beyond all reasonable doubt but that it had to prove one last fact, namely, federal insurance as a prerequisite to conviction.

The Illinois principle contention is that by adopting the Constitution of United States, the Bill of Rights and the Fourteenth Amendment, the States didn't conceive and nobody has conceived that they were abdicating their right to try for and punish crimes of violence against persons and properties within their territories.

Should the Federal Government undertake to make the same acts criminal particularly when there's no suggestion that the Federal Government has preempted the field, and any such suggestion is explicitly disclaimed by Mr. Fisher in his argument in this case.

So to hold, would be to hold that the Constitution was a compact by which the States have, in some manner, compromised or abridged or abdicated their power to punish such simple crimes of violence as robbery should the Federal Government prosecute in and earlier case.
Now, Mr. Fisher raises other questions.

He says that even if Illinois might retry this -- this petitioner and might be trying these crimes in general, due process is denied because federal officials were active in the prosecution and procurement of the conviction which is under review in this case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't know why judges do badly, they do sometimes.
Not only in Chicago either.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: Oh, I know (Inaudible)

He has appended to his brief as appendix in his -- at page -- pages 90 through page 94, excerpts of (Inaudible) those excerpts are not at any place in this record printed or unprinted, so I'm unable to answer Your Honor's question.
But even supposing that the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, I'm merely suggesting that a state-initiated, the state pursue, state-conducted prosecution in the course of which the State call as an official, as a competent witness to testify for something or happens to be (Inaudible) is the federal official based it as a -- of the -- the fact or fact.

I don't know what the illegal consequences but you may be wholly right, a different thing from having a federal judge get the, plus the FBI, get the state machinery going to bring about that result as a -- as fact, that's different.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: As a fact, it is different.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not sure the difference equals to the due process.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: I suggest that it's a difference without constitutional consequences.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That -- that may well be.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: The -- the position of Illinois in this case is that if we can prosecute at all, it makes no difference as to the instant we prosecute or how much help we get so long as the help that we get isn't tainted by any intrinsic illegality such as the evidence that having been illegally obtained or they're being bribery by fellow officials or sovereign agent or forgery or anything of that sort, none of which is claimed, mostly candid, in this case.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Wines, the word "intrinsic" covers the problem.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: Oh, of course, it does Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Entrapment and in the prosecution induced by the entrapment (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- vitiated the prosecution (Inaudible) and say that was intrinsically illegal rather --

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All I'm suggesting is --

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: -- I mean it would be illegal --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) de facto may make a difference.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: I mean it would be illegal apart from any question of former acquittal.
That's -- that's what I really mean, Your Honor.
In other words, I say that Illinois isn't to prosecute at all or maybe we can.
We can take any measures that we could have taken and it's not been for this former federal trial.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If you can prosecute, you say you can prosecute effectively.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: Effectively and at the instance of anybody.
That is the contention of the State of Illinois, so far as this former trial is concerned.
Now, Mr. Fisher also raises a question in his brief which he did not have time to discuss, but which I wish to mention very briefly.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: May -- may I know revert at the first -- of the three contention that Mr. Fisher had adopted.

I understand Illinois, your position, could be that assuming identity, carbon copy of the element of a crime, short of the one that you've indicated, and I'll say why you shrink from that, assuming that identity proves in a prosecution of state court which was preceded by quid pro in the federal court, you say that such separation of power, that means the two governments that due process does not absorb that which would be clearly double jeopardy.
It -- it had acquired merely in the federal court, is that right?

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: Yes, that's right.
I don't want to leave any misapprehension on that point at all.
And I pointed out --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: The two powers are compartmentalized constitutionally.

turn.speaker: william_c_wines
turn.label: Mr. William C. Wines
turn.text: That's what I say, Your Honor.
Now, Mr. Fisher raises one other point in his brief which he did not discuss in his oral argument and I want to discuss it only briefly.

In the trial in Illinois, some of petitioner's witnesses were cross-examined as their testimony from the transcripts of the federal court proceedings in the usual manner, "Weren't you asked such and such a question and didn't you make such and such a reply?"
The defendant sought to introduce evidence in the state court that he had been acquitted in the federal court.
The trial judge in the state court refused to permit the jury in a state court to know the verdict in the federal court.
And it's contended in the brief that that rule denies due process of law.
We say that that question raises only a question of evidence, it being the very well set of general rule that one jury is not to be told what another jury did with the same case.
It's a -- generally speaking, one jury has never told what a former jury in that or any other court decided.

Now, it is true that -- no, had -- had petitioner been convicted in the federal court instead of acquitted, the State couldn't have shown that conviction as proof of guilt in this case though they might have used it to impeach him if he testified.
But we say that that's outmost the question, a question of state law and not a federal law.

So to sum up Illinois' position in this case, we say, if Your Honors please, that the overwhelming consensus of opinion has been up until certiorari was granted in this case that conviction or acquittal in a federal court does not by a retrial in a state court for the same facts or vice versa.

We note in this case that proof of an additional fact, namely, the presence of federal insurance was required in the federal case, we say that if we can prosecute at all, we can prosecute with the full aid and even at the instance of federal prosecutors provided that no illicitly obtained evidence is used or other illicit means are used to prosecute the case, we can prosecute just as though there had been no federal trial and we say that no error in intervened in failure to tell the jury in the state court that petitioner had been acquitted in the federal court.
By those considerations, we respectfully submit this case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Fisher.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and Justices, irrespective of who initiated this proceeding, the federal agents did not merely testify in the state court, they proceeded to prepare the case, the interview of witnesses and, as I have said, they dug up a new witness.
They continued in their official capacities to carry on what I understand is forbidden by the double jeopardy provision of the Fifth Amendment, so much for that.
As for the case of Palko, Palko only approved the second trial in the same proceeding and where illegal error came in the first trial.

In other words, Palko held that the State is entitled to appeal and obtain for itself one errorless trial but it was expressly -- it was expressly accepted in the Palko case, the -- the -- any decision on the matter before there was a new and different proceeding.
And if ordered liberty means anything, it means I can't think of anything more just orderly than to have relitigation of completed cases in which a final judgment has been entered.
Now, the case of Parker against McClure that Mr. Wines referred to is like so many cases both in this Court and other courts on this question that are said to be against us.
They are not double jeopardy cases at all.
It was only one trial.
It was simply dicta useful for argument in the one trial.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Fisher, before you sit down, I would like to express appreciation of the Court to you for having undertaken this assignment for this indigent prisoner.
It's always reassuring to us to know that there are lawyers who devote themselves earnestly to causes of that kind such as you have here, and we thank you for the service you rendered.
It is a public service.

Mr. Wines, I would like to say to you also that we appreciate the fair and earnest manner in which you have defended the rights of the people of your State and that -- that gentleman is without regard to the outcome of this case.

turn.speaker: walter_t_fisher
turn.label: Mr. Walter T. Fisher
turn.text: Thank you for your expression, Mr. Chief Justice.
